original_title: Bronx: Boston Road - Pelham Parkway South
text:
Boston Road (trolley tracks thereon), north from Pelham Parkway South to White Plains Road. Also shown is the Pelham Parkway station and part of the elevated trestle of the I.R.T. White Plains Road subway line on the latter thoroughfare. The station straddles the entire breadth of the Bronx and Pelham Parkway. White Plains Road runs directly north, whereas Boston Road proceeds in a northeasterly direction.

James Suydam.

1917.

Bronx and Pelham Parkway, east from Boston Road, showing, straddling the entire width of the Parkway, the Pelham Parkway elevated station of the I.R.T. White Plains Road subway line on the latter thoroughfare. The driveway in the foreground is Pelham Parkway South.

James Suydam.

1917.
title: Bronx: Bronx and Pelham Par - Boston Road

text:
E. Tremont Avenue, east from Boston Road. On the extreme right is E. 177th Street, proceeding east from Devoe Avenue, and to its left is Wyatt Street, running east from Devoe Avenue. Also visible is the elevated structure of the New York, Boston and Westchester Railroad.

May 1926

Brown Brothers

original_title: Bronx: Boston Road - Pelham Parkway South
text:
Boston Road, at the S.E. corner of Pelham Parkway South. On the extreme left appears part of the Pelham Parkway station of the White Plains Road I.R.T. subway.
July 28, 1928
P. L. Sperr

Bronx Park: A view of Public School No. 57 Annex, situated about one hundred yards west of Boston Road and about 150 yards south of Pelham Parkway. It stood formerly on the north side of the old White Plains Road within the village of Bronxdale. The village was later (after 1900) incorporated into Bronx Park. The school was demolished sometime after 1930.

July 28, 1928

P.L. Sperr
title: Bronx: Bronx Park - P.S. 57 Annex (Bronxdale).

text:
E. Tremont Avenue, south side (foreground), east from Boston Road to the Bronx River. Also shown is the New York Coliseum, on the south side of E. 177th Street, adjoining Devoe Avenue. The view is northeastward from the E. 177th Street elevated station of the I.R.T. subway.

May 11, 1938.

P.L. Sperr

E. Tremont Avenue, north side, west from the Bronx River to Boston Road. This is a central meeting point for a number of street car lines of the Third Avenue Street Railway Company. Shown, too, is the Tremont Avenue station of the I. R. T.

July 23, 1940

P. L. Sperr
